page.title: 09Old Red House Farm (cont)
page.content: At Red House Farm,{silage}is made in two ways.Firstly,{contractors}come to the Farm with an enormous machine and make{grass "clamps"}which are put in between the Farm walls.The rest is made into big round bales and stored in large plastic bags.To do this work our own{baler}is used.It is also used to help other farmers in the area to bale their silage or straw.On the Farm we also keep about five or six young calves,which we buy and suckle on four nurse cows.These are then sold again when they are bigger.There are twelve {hens}in the yard which are kept for eggs. There are usually enough for the family and for friends. Two people run the farm,working as partners. The farmhouse buildings are estimated to be some{250 years old}and the Farm itself was part of the{Ammerdown {Estate}until 1905.
